newsitem.title: SAUDI ARABIA: GCC official says better relations up to Iran.
newsitem.headline: GCC official says better relations up to Iran.

text.p: Gulf Arab states remain concerned about Iran's political and military policies and believe it was up to Tehran to prove it was sincere about improving relations, a Gulf official said on Thursday.

The foreign ministers of the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) -- a six-nation political and military alliance -- on Wednesday welcomed Iranian attempts to mend fences and commended the non-Arab country's new outlook as expressed by Iranian Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Velayati on a regional tour this month.
"Foreign Minister Velayati was actively trying to improve relations," said Abdullah al-Khulaifi, a GCC assistant secretary-general.
"But only time will tell how true his statements are," he told Reuters. "Hopefully from the Iranian side the words will match the actions. The ball is in their court."
The GCC had called on Iran to respect the internal affairs of each country in the alliance, which groups Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain and Oman.
"We have worries about Iran's militarisation, its increasing military presence on the UAE islands. We are concerned about the UAE's rights," Khulaifi said.

Velayati toured the six oil-rich Gulf states this month and said the visits helped open a new chapter in relations. Days later, Iranian President Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani and Saudi Crown Prince Abdullah met at an Islamic summit in Islamabad.
Gulf Arab states have accused Iran of interfering in their internal affairs -- a charge Iran denies -- and have voiced concern over its arms buildup. Iran says its arms programme is defensive.
A sore point in Iran's relations with its Arab neighbours is a long-standing territorial dispute between it and the UAE over three strategic Gulf islands.
